name: oilrig

procedures: T1003.001::[OilRig] has used credential dumping tools such as [Mimikatz] to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.
T1003.004::[OilRig] has used credential dumping tools such as [LaZagne] to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.
T1003.005::[OilRig] has used credential dumping tools such as [LaZagne] to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.
T1007::[OilRig] has used sc query on a victim to gather information about services.
T1008::[OilRig] malware ISMAgent falls back to its DNS tunneling mechanism if it is unable to reach the C2 server over HTTP.
T1012::[OilRig] has used reg query “HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Default” on a victim to query the Registry.
T1016::[OilRig] has run ipconfig /all on a victim.
T1021.001::[OilRig] has used Remote Desktop Protocol for lateral movement. The group has also used tunneling tools to tunnel RDP into the environment.
T1021.004::[OilRig] has used Putty to access compromised systems.
T1027.005::[OilRig] has tested malware samples to determine AV detection and subsequently modified the samples to ensure AV evasion.
T1027::[OilRig] has encrypted and encoded data in its malware, including by using base64.
T1033::[OilRig] has run whoami on a victim.
T1036::[OilRig] has used .doc file extensions to mask malicious executables.
T1046::[OilRig] has used the publicly available tool SoftPerfect Network Scanner as well as a custom tool called GOLDIRONY to conduct network scanning.
T1047::[OilRig] has used WMI for execution.
T1048.003::[OilRig] has exfiltrated data over FTP separately from its primary C2 channel over DNS.
T1049::[OilRig] has used netstat -an on a victim to get a listing of network connections.
T1053.005::[OilRig] has created scheduled tasks that run a VBScript to execute a payload on victim machines.
T1056.001::[OilRig] has used keylogging tools called KEYPUNCH and LONGWATCH.
T1057::[OilRig] has run tasklist on a victim's machine.
T1059.001::[OilRig] has used PowerShell scripts for execution, including use of a macro to run a PowerShell command to decode file contents.
T1059.003::[OilRig] has used macros to deliver malware such as [QUADAGENT] and [OopsIE].
T1059.005::[OilRig] has used VBSscipt macros for execution on compromised hosts.
T1059::[OilRig] has used various types of scripting for execution.
T1069.001::[OilRig] has used net localgroup administrators to find local administrators on compromised systems.
T1069.002::[OilRig] has used net group /domain, net group “domain admins” /domain, and net group “Exchange Trusted Subsystem” /domain to find domain group permission settings.
T1070.004::[OilRig] has deleted files associated with their payload after execution.
T1071.001::[OilRig] has used HTTP for C2.
T1071.004::[OilRig] has used DNS for C2 including the publicly available requestbin.net tunneling service.
T1078::[OilRig] has used compromised credentials to access other systems on a victim network.
T1082::[OilRig] has run hostname and systeminfo on a victim.
T1087.001::[OilRig] has run net user, net user /domain, net group “domain admins” /domain, and net group “Exchange Trusted Subsystem” /domain to get account listings on a victim.
T1087.002::[OilRig] has run net user, net user /domain, net group “domain admins” /domain, and net group “Exchange Trusted Subsystem” /domain to get account listings on a victim.
T1105::[OilRig] can download remote files onto victims.
T1110::[OilRig] has used brute force techniques to obtain credentials.
T1113::[OilRig] has a tool called CANDYKING to capture a screenshot of user's desktop.
T1119::[OilRig] has used automated collection.
T1120::[OilRig] has used tools to identify if a mouse is connected to a targeted system.
T1133::[OilRig] uses remote services such as VPN, Citrix, or OWA to persist in an environment.
T1137.004::[OilRig] has abused the Outlook Home Page feature for persistence. [OilRig] has also used CVE-2017-11774 to roll back the initial patch designed to protect against Home Page abuse.
T1140::A [OilRig] macro has run a PowerShell command to decode file contents. [OilRig] has also used [certutil] to decode base64-encoded files on victims.
T1201::[OilRig] has used net.exe in a script with net accounts /domain to find the password policy of a domain.
T1204.001::[OilRig] has delivered malicious links to achieve execution on the target system.
T1204.002::[OilRig] has delivered macro-enabled documents that required targets to click the "enable content" button to execute the payload on the system.
T1218.001::[OilRig] has used a CHM payload to load and execute another malicious file once delivered to a victim.
T1497.001::[OilRig] has used macros to verify if a mouse is connected to a compromised machine.
T1505.003::[OilRig] has used web shells, often to maintain access to a victim network.
T1552.001::[OilRig] has used credential dumping tools such as [LaZagne] to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.
T1555.003::[OilRig] has used credential dumping tools such as [LaZagne] to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.
T1555.004::[OilRig] has used credential dumping tool named VALUEVAULT to steal credentials from the Windows Credential Manager.
T1555::[OilRig] has used credential dumping tools such as [LaZagne] to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.
T1566.001::[OilRig] has sent spearphising emails with malicious attachments to potential victims using compromised and/or spoofed email accounts.
T1566.002::[OilRig] has sent spearphising emails with malicious links to potential victims.
T1566.003::[OilRig] has used LinkedIn to send spearphishing links.
T1572::[OilRig] has used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.
T1573.002::[OilRig] used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.

description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) is a suspected Iranian threat group that has targeted Middle Eastern and international victims since at least 2014. The group has targeted a variety of sectors, including financial, government, energy, chemical, and telecommunications. It appears the group carries out supply chain attacks, leveraging the trust relationship between organizations to attack their primary targets. FireEye assesses that the group works on behalf of the Iranian government based on infrastructure details that contain references to Iran, use of Iranian infrastructure, and targeting that aligns with nation-state interests.(Citation: Palo Alto OilRig April 2017)(Citation: ClearSky OilRig Jan 2017)(Citation: Palo Alto OilRig May 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto OilRig Oct 2016)(Citation: Unit42 OilRig Playbook 2023)(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)
